t: Song of Solomon 1
The*pn Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
Woman
Oh,*pn that he would kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For*ln your caresses are more delightful than wine.
The*ln fragrance of your perfume is intoxicating; your*ln name is perfume poured out. No*ln wonder young women adore you.
Take*ln me with you- let’s hurry. Oh,*ln that the king would bring me to his chambers.
Young Women
We*pn will rejoice and be glad in you; we*ln will celebrate your caresses more than wine.
Woman
It*pn is only right that they adore you.
Daughters*pn of Jerusalem, I*ln am dark like the tents of Kedar, yet*ln lovely like the curtains of Solomon.

Do*ln not stare at me because I am dark, for*ln the sun has gazed on me. My*ln mother’s sons were angry with me; they*ln made me take care of the vineyards. I*ln have not taken care of my own vineyard.
Tell*pn me, you whom I love: Where*ln do you pasture your sheep? Where*ln do you let them rest at noon? Why*ln should I be like one who veils herself beside*ln the flocks of your companions?
Man
If*pn you do not know, most*ln beautiful of women, follow*ln the tracks of the flock, and*ln pasture your young goats near*ln the shepherds’ tents.
I*pn compare you, my darling, to*ln a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
Your*ln cheeks are beautiful with jewelry, your*ln neck with its necklace.
We*ln will make gold jewelry for you, accented*ln with silver.
Woman
While*pn the king is on his couch, my*ln perfume releases its fragrance.
The*ln one I love is a sachet of myrrh to me, spending*ln the night between my breasts.
The*ln one I love is a cluster of henna blossoms to me, in*ln the vineyards of En-gedi.
Man
How*pn beautiful you are, my darling. How*ln very beautiful! Your*ln eyes are doves.
Woman
How*pn handsome you are, my love. How*ln delightful! Our*ln bed is verdant;
the*ln beams of our house are cedars, and*ln our rafters are cypresses.
Song of Solomon 2
I*pn am a wildflower of Sharon, a*ln lily of the valleys.
Man
Like*pn a lily among thorns, so*ln is my darling among the young women.
Woman
Like*pn an apricot tree among the trees of the forest, so*ln is my love among the young men. I*ln delight to sit in his shade, and*ln his fruit is sweet to my taste.
He*ln brought me to the banquet hall, and*ln he looked on me with love.
Sustain*ln me with raisins; refresh*ln me with apricots, for*ln I am lovesick.
May*ln his left hand be under my head, and*ln his right arm embrace me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ln the gazelles and the wild does of the field, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Listen!*pn My love is approaching. Look!*ln Here he comes, leaping*ln over the mountains, bounding*ln over the hills.
My*ln love is like a gazelle or*ln a young stag. See,*ln he is standing behind our wall, gazing*ln through the windows, peering*ln through the lattice.
My*ln love calls to me:
Man
Arise,*pn my darling. Come*ln away, my beautiful one.
For*ln now the winter is past; the*ln rain has ended and gone away.
The*ln blossoms appear in the countryside. The*ln time of singing has come, and*ln the turtledove’s cooing is heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree ripens its figs; the*ln blossoming vines give off their fragrance. Arise,*ln my darling. Come*ln away, my beautiful one.
My*pn dove, in the clefts of the rock, in*ln the crevices of the cliff, let*ln me see your face, let*ln me hear your voice; for*ln your voice is sweet, and*ln your face is lovely.
Woman
Catch*pn the foxes for us— the*ln little foxes that ruin the vineyards — for*ln our vineyards are in bloom.
Woman
My*pn love is mine and I am his; he*ln feeds among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ln the shadows flee, turn*ln around, my love, and be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on the divided mountains.
Song of Solomon 3
In*pn my bed at night I*ln sought the one I love; I*ln sought him, but did not find him.
I*ln will arise now and go about the city, through*ln the streets and the plazas. I*ln will seek the one I love. I*ln sought him, but did not find him.
The*ln guards who go about the city found me. I*ln asked them, “Have you seen the one I love?”
I*ln had just passed them when*ln I found the one I love. I*ln held on to him and would not let him go until*ln I brought him to my mother’s house— to*ln the chamber of the one who conceived me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ln the gazelles and the wild does of the field, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Narrator
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness like*ln columns of smoke, scented*ln with myrrh and frankincense from*ln every fragrant powder of the merchant?
Look!*pn Solomon’s bed surrounded*ln by sixty warriors from*ln the mighty men of Israel.
All*ln of them are skilled with swords and*ln trained in warfare. Each*ln has his sword at his side to*ln guard against the terror of the night.
King*pn Solomon made a carriage for himself with*ln wood from Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, its*ln back of gold, and*ln its seat of purple. Its*ln interior is inlaid with love by*ln the young women of Jerusalem.
Go*ln out, young women of Zion, and*ln gaze at King Solomon, wearing*ln the crown his mother placed on him on*ln the day of his wedding— the*ln day of his heart’s rejoicing.
Song of Solomon 4
Man
How*pn beautiful you are, my darling. How*ln very beautiful! Behind*ln your veil, your*ln eyes are doves. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats streaming*ln down Mount Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of newly shorn sheep coming*ln up from washing, each*ln one bearing twins, and*ln none has lost its young.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet cord, and*ln your mouth is lovely. Behind*ln your veil, your*ln brow is like a slice of pomegranate.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, constructed*ln in layers. A*ln thousand shields are hung on it — all*ln of them shields of warriors.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, twins*ln of a gazelle, that feed among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ln the shadows flee, I*ln will make my way to the mountain of myrrh and*ln the hill of frankincense.
You*ln are absolutely beautiful, my darling; there*ln is no imperfection in you.

Come*pn with me from Lebanon, my bride; come*ln with me from Lebanon! Descend*ln from the peak of Amana, from*ln the summit of Senir and Hermon, from*ln the dens of the lions, from*ln the mountains of the leopards.
You*ln have captured my heart, my sister, my bride. You*ln have captured my heart with one glance of your eyes, with*ln one jewel of your necklace.
How*ln delightful your caresses are, my sister, my bride. Your*ln caresses are much better than wine, and*ln the fragrance of your perfume than any balsam.
Your*ln lips drip sweetness like the honeycomb, my bride. Honey*ln and milk are under your tongue. The*ln fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
My*pn sister, my bride, you are a locked garden — a*ln locked garden and a sealed spring.
Your*ln branches are a paradise of pomegranates with*ln choicest fruits; henna*ln with nard,
nard*ln and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with*ln all the trees of frankincense, myrrh*ln and aloes, with*ln all the best spices.
You*ln are a garden spring, a*ln well of flowing water streaming*ln from Lebanon.
Woman
Awaken,*pn north wind; come,*ln south wind. Blow*ln on my garden, and*ln spread the fragrance of its spices. Let*ln my love come to his garden and*ln eat its choicest fruits.
Song of Solomon 5
Man
I*pn have come to my garden - my sister, my bride. I*ln gather my myrrh with my spices. I*ln eat my honeycomb with my honey. I*ln drink my wine with my milk.
Narrator
Eat,*pn friends! Drink,*ln be intoxicated with caresses!
Woman
I*pn was sleeping, but my heart was awake. A*ln sound! My love was knocking!
Man
Open*pn to me, my sister, my darling, my*ln dove, my perfect one. For*ln my head is drenched with dew, my*ln hair with droplets of the night.
Woman
I*pn have taken off my clothing. How*ln can I put it back on? I*ln have washed my feet. How*ln can I get them dirty?
My*ln love thrust his hand through the opening, and*ln my feelings were stirred for him.
I*ln rose to open for my love. My*ln hands dripped with myrrh, my*ln fingers with flowing myrrh on*ln the handles of the bolt.
I*ln opened to my love, but*ln my love had turned and gone away. My*ln heart sank because he had left. I*ln sought him, but did not find him. I*ln called him, but he did not answer.
The*ln guards who go about the city found me. They*ln beat and wounded me; they*ln took my cloak from me — the*ln guardians of the walls.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you, if*ln you find my love, tell*ln him that I am lovesick.
Young Women
What*pn makes the one you love better than another, most*ln beautiful of women? What*ln makes him better than another, that*ln you would give us this charge?
Woman
My*pn love is fit and strong, notable*ln among ten thousand.
His*pn head is purest gold. His*ln hair is wavy and*ln black as a raven.
His*ln eyes are like doves beside*ln flowing streams, washed*ln in milk and*ln set like jewels.
His*ln cheeks are like beds of spice, mounds*ln of perfume. His*ln lips are lilies, dripping*ln with flowing myrrh.
His*ln arms are rods of gold set*ln with beryl. His*ln body is an ivory panel covered*ln with lapis lazuli.
His*ln legs are alabaster pillars set*ln on pedestals of pure gold. His*ln presence is like Lebanon, as*ln majestic as the cedars.
His*ln mouth is sweetness. He*ln is absolutely desirable. This*ln is my love, and this is my friend, young*ln women of Jerusalem.
Song of Solomon 6
Young Women
Where*pn has your love gone, most*ln beautiful of women? Which*ln way has he turned? We*ln will seek him with you.
Woman
My*pn love has gone down to his garden, to*ln beds of spice, to*ln feed in the gardens and*ln gather lilies.
I*ln am my love’s and my love is mine; he*ln feeds among the lilies.
Man
You*pn are as beautiful as Tirzah, my darling, lovely*ln as Jerusalem, awe-inspiring*ln as an army with banners.
Turn*ln your eyes away from me, for*ln they captivate me. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats streaming*ln down from Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of ewes coming*ln up from washing, each*ln one having a twin, and*ln not one missing.
Behind*ln your veil, your*ln brow is like a slice of pomegranate.
There*ln are sixty queens and*ln eighty concubines and*ln young women without number.

But*ln my dove, my virtuous one, is unique; she*ln is the favorite of her mother, perfect*ln to the one who gave her birth. Women*ln see her and declare her fortunate; queens*ln and concubines also, and they sing her praises:
Who*ln is this who shines like the dawn, as*ln beautiful as the moon, bright*ln as the sun, awe-inspiring*ln as an army with banners?
Woman
I*pn came down to the walnut grove to*ln see the blossoms of the valley, to*ln see if the vines were budding and*ln the pomegranates blooming.
I*ln didn’t know what was happening to me. I*ln felt like I was in*ln a chariot with a nobleman.
Young Women
Come*pn back, come back, Shulammite! Come*ln back, come back, that we may look at you!
Man
How*pn you gaze at the Shulammite, as*ln you look at the dance of the two camps!
Song of Solomon 7
How*pn beautiful are your sandaled feet, princess! The*ln curves of your thighs are like jewelry, the*ln handiwork of a master.
Your*ln navel is a rounded bowl; it*ln never lacks mixed wine. Your*ln belly is a mound of wheat surrounded*ln by lilies.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, twins*ln of a gazelle.
Your*ln neck is like a tower of ivory, your*ln eyes like pools in Heshbon by*ln Bath-rabbim’s gate. Your*ln nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking*ln toward Damascus.
Your*ln head crowns you like Mount Carmel, the*ln hair of your head like purple cloth — a*ln king could be held captive in your tresses.
How*ln beautiful you are and how pleasant, my*ln love, with such delights!
Your*ln stature is like a palm tree; your*ln breasts are clusters of fruit.
I*ln said, “I will climb the palm tree and*ln take hold of its fruit.” May*ln your breasts be like clusters of grapes, and*ln the fragrance of your breath like apricots.
Your*ln mouth is like fine wine—
Woman
flowing*pn smoothly for my love, gliding*ln past my lips and teeth!
I*ln am my love’s, and*ln his desire is for me.
Come,*pn my love, let’s*ln go to the field; let’s*ln spend the night among the henna blossoms.
Let’s*ln go early to the vineyards; let’s*ln see if the vine has budded, if*ln the blossom has opened, if*ln the pomegranates are in bloom. There*ln I will give you my caresses.
The*ln mandrakes give off a fragrance, and*ln at our doors is every delicacy, both*ln new and old. I*ln have treasured them up for you, my love.
Song of Solomon 8
If*pn only I could treat you like my brother, one*ln who nursed at my mother’s breasts, I*ln would find you in public and kiss you, and*ln no one would scorn me.
I*ln would lead you, I would take you, to*ln the house of my mother who taught me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink from*ln the juice of my pomegranate.
May*ln his left hand be under my head, and*ln his right arm embrace me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Young Women
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning*ln on the one she loves?
Woman
I*pn awakened you under the apricot tree. There*ln your mother conceived you; there*ln she conceived and gave you birth.
Set*ln me as a seal on your heart, as*ln a seal on your arm. For*ln love is as strong as death; jealousy*ln is as unrelenting as Sheol. Love’s*ln flames are fiery flames— an*ln almighty flame!
A*ln huge torrent cannot extinguish love; rivers*ln cannot sweep it away. If*ln a man were to give all his wealth for love, it*ln would be utterly scorned.
Brothers
Our*pn sister is young; she*ln has no breasts. What*ln will we do for our sister on*ln the day she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ln will build a silver barricade on her. If*ln she is a door, we*ln will enclose her with cedar planks.
Woman
I*pn am a wall and*ln my breasts like towers. So*ln to him I have become like*ln one who finds peace.
Solomon*pn owned a vineyard in Baal-hamon. He*ln leased the vineyard to tenants. Each*ln was to bring for his fruit one*ln thousand pieces of silver.
I*ln have my own vineyard. The*ln one thousand are for you, Solomon, but*ln two hundred for those who take care of its fruits.
Man
You*pn who dwell in the gardens, companions*ln are listening for your voice; let*ln me hear you!
Woman
Run*pn away with me, my love, and*ln be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on*ln the mountains of spices.
